THE BROTHERS FOUR

The University Prom, featuring Billy Butterfield and the Brothers Four, will be held
in the Fifth Regiment Armory on Saturday,
March 10 from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Dress will be
semi-formal.
Tickets will cost three dollars per couple
for undergraduates, five dollars for others and
may be obtained at Levering, the Dorm Cafeteria, the Student Valet Service, or from
members of the Cotillion Board, the H-Club,
The Booster Club, the I.F.C., the Student
Council and the D.S.R.C. Graduate students
and students of McCoy College may get tickets
at the Bookstore or in Levering. Tickets will
also be on sale at the Registrar's office at the
Med School.
The Cotillion Board has stressed that no
efforts have been spared to make this Prom
the best in the history of Hopkins. The favors
and decorations are designed to be truly
memorable and to harmonize with the particular tonal qualities of the Billy Butterfield

Orchestra. It is hoped that this harmony will
lend an aesthetic unity to the dance as a
whole and thus make it a more pleasant experience.
In order to insure the financial success of
the dance, members of the graduate departments, Medical School and employees are
being actively solicited. It is stressed that this
is a function for the whole Hopkins Community, not only for the undergraduates. It is
hoped that many grad students, medical students and employees will attend.
..Table reservations are available from Terry
Sinclair, 285 - 1868, until one week before the
dance. No reservations will be accepted after
March 3.
John Wetzig, Chairman of the dance committee issued the following statement, "We
really hope all you fellows will have a real
good time at the Prom. We have put a lot of
work into it and we really think that this will
help to liven up the old Homewood."

At Shriver

By Matt Crenson
Mr. Harry Golden, essayist, journalist,
and shirtsleeve philosopher from the South,
is scheduled to speak at Shriver Hall this
Sunday evening in a program sponsored by
the YMCA and Student Council. The talk,
by the editor of the Carolina Israelite, will
bring to a close Brotherhood Week activities at Hopkins.
Mr. Golden is the author of three books,
the first of which, Only in America, sold
over two million copies and was translated
into fifty-four languages. He is about to
publish a fourth—a collection of essays
called You're Entitle.
Born in New York, Golden was educated
at the East Side Evening High School and
CCNY, taught elementary school for two
years, and worked as a reporter for two
New York newspapers. In 1941 he moved
to Charlotte, North Carolina, where he took
over the Israelite, which then
commanded a subscription list of
400. Circulation has subsequently
risen to more than 300,000.

HARRY GOLDEN

A referendum will be submitted to the student body on
the following Tuesday, March 6,
to at which time a vote will
be taken to decide whether or
not to institute the Gentleman's
Code Commission. The proposal
must receive a simple majority
of those voting in order to pass.
Earlier Elections
At the same time the Council
will ask for student approval of
an amendment to its Constitution which would move the date
of Student Council elections
from late in April to late in
March. Under the new plan
elections would be held just before Spring Vacation.

MILTON EISENHOWER

In advocating this change Bob
Abernethy, President of the
Student Council, stated that he
felt that the new system would

be a great improvement because
it would allow the new council
an extra month to get its
projects under way before the
closing of school. This, Abernethy felt, would make for con-.
siderably less confusion in the
fall.
For Losers
As a part of the new election
procedure it is proposed that the
elections for President of the
Council be held one week before
the election of Council members.
This would give defeated candidates for President a chance
to run for the Council and thus
not exclude potentially valuable
men from student government.

While there was widespread
support for this proposal, at least
one Council member remarked
that if this plan were put into
effect the council would soon
become "a group of losers."

THE BELL TELEPHONE COMPANIES
SALUTE: DON McCAHAN
When a new telephone building goes up in his area, Don
McCahan will be found right in the center of activity. It's
Don's responsibility to work closely with the architects in
developing blueprints, also to follow up to be sure construction meets specifications. A lot of responsibility for
a young engineer just two years out of college, but a lot of

satisfaction, too. Because Don knows that his contributions
lead to better telephone service for his community.
Don McCahan of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, and the other young engineers like him in Bell
Telephone Companies throughout the country, help make
your communications service the finest in the world.

The Defeated One?
The Student Council this week passed an interesting constitutional amendment requiring elections for
the president of the Council to be held one week prior
to the election for Student Council representatives.
The avowed purpose of this amendment is to make
sure that no "campus leaders" are prevented from serving on the Council. In other words, if a presidential
candidate loses, he may still run for representative. A
sponsor of this amendment was Bill Brandon. Our only
question is whether defeatism has set in at such an early
date.

By nature student government either is or is not;
there can be no half-way state. The ideal of all student government is the situation where the students
assume complete responsibility for their conduct, their
organizations, and their discipline. Opposed to this is
the situation where the administration assumes all these
functions.
If we admit that the college student is an adult,
then he should be allowed to govern himself completely
and without interference. If this is denied, there is no
reason to have any student government at all.
The half and half combination favored on this
rampus can not succeed. Like all governments subject
to two masters our student government is forced to
please everybody simultaneously. Patently, this situation
can not be permanently maintained with corresponding
loss of confidence in the student government by both
administration and student bodies.
For student government to be meaningful it must
Lave complete responsibility for all student affairs including discipline, legislation, and finance. The function of the dean should be merely advisory, not directive.
In this situation student government passes from
the trivial to the important. The actual policies of the
government may be laissez-faire or controlled depending on the wishes of the student body. But the decisions
would be made solely by the student body according
to their desires and interests without reference to any
other master.

At long last the American student seems anxious to
shake off his tratltional political apathy. Last weekend
thousands of American students from all over the nation converged on Washington, D.C. in a truly impressive
ad moving demonstration of student unity and determination. They made the pilgrimage in order to impress the United States government and people with
the urgency of effecting a lasting peace in the world
and with the uselessness of bomb shelters.
The appeal was eloquent. It could not be passed off
I
as the idea of crack-pot leftists or that of immature
youngsters. President John Kennedy recognized the
legitimacy of student concern for international affairs—
going so far as to order that a large urn of coffee be
sent out to picketers pacing in front of the White House.
Inside the White House, three of his top aides met cordially with student representatives and discussed the
problem. The students got short shrift from Congressmen, but then again what more could be expected from
those gentlemen.
The reason for this rebirth of student political
411.
activity is still unclear. It remains microscopic compared
to students peace movements in Europe and Asia. But
in passing we note that it is occurring at the same time
as the conservative factions on campuses have become
somewhat more active. It is also accompanied by a corresponding decline in the power and prestige of campus
student government organization all over the country.

HUG's Abject Apology
The Hopkins Undergraduate Goals Committee
:(HUG) has issued a second letter in order to make up
for the first letter, which apparently failed to "make
.. (its) purposes clear." But after reading all about
11`human nature" and "faculty facilities and tactics" we
are thoroughly unimpressed. The clumsily worded letter is nothing more than an abject apology for the existence of the committee. As the committee "keeps the
iNtudents' needs before the administration" we hope they

Fifty-sixth Street, is formally the
home of the Phi Gamma Delta
Club. And the Hopkins Club, together with the Stevens Institute
of Technology, the Syracuse and
the Metropolitan Clubs, do but
share the facilities of Phi Gamma
Delta.
That Old Hospitality
There is no doorman to await
one's arrival or to signify the
presence of the Club, so it is quite
usual to pass the entrance several
times before going in. Should one
enter in a black and blue packet
labeled "HOPKINS," he will be
shaken to the rude realization
that no one has or will approach
him with a friendly handshake,
to inquire if the old place is still
located on the Homewood campus.

There are nine floors to the
narrow building. On the second
may indeed be found a library
and a lounge, as stipulated by the
advertisement. The library is not
bright and doesn't have many
books; if it is richly paneled, one
could hardly note the fact since
the walls are quite liberally
adorned with framed documents
of the Phi Gamma Delta Club.
The lounge has most likely been
designed in imitation of a Charles
Dickens description of the solemn
old English drawing-room. As in
the library, a considerable dearth
of light makes itself felt. There
is, however, a piano in the corner.
The Setting
Some might substantiate the
Club's claim that it possesses
"outstanding" facilities. From the
windows facing the street one
gets an excellent panorama of
life in downtown New York.
There is a construction project
directly across the street, adding
greatly to the setting's local color
and general impact.
And, if one looks hard enough,
he might even find a plaque stating "Johns Hopkins Slept Here."
But that's highly doubtful.

UNITED WE STAND
The entire academic world is agog over the success of the
Associated Colleges Plan—ACP, for short. I mean, you go to
any campus in the country these days and you will see students
and faculty dancing on the green, blowing penny whistles,
grabbing each other by the elbows and yelling, "About that
ACP, Charley—like wow!"
And who can blame them? The ACP is a plan not only simply
brilliant, but also brilliantly simple. All it is, is a loose regional
federation of small colleges. Let's say, for example, that in a
given region we have a group of small colleges, each with its
own academic specialty. Small College No. 1, let's say,has a fine
language department; Small College No. 2, let's say, has a fine
science department; No.3 has a fine music department; etc., etc.
Well sir, under the ACP these various colleges federate. A
student in any one of the colleges can take courses in the specialty of any of the other colleges and—here's the beauty part!
—he will receive credit for the course at his home college. Thus
he enjoys all the advantages of a big university without losing
the comfy coziness of a small college!
Well sir, you can see what a good idea the ACP is. I respectfully submit, however, that just because a thing is good is no
reason not to try to make it better. Like,for instance, Marlboro
Cigarettes. Marlboros were good from the very beginning, and
people found out quickly and sales zoomed. But did the makers
of Marlboro say, "Okay, we've got it made. Let's relax"?
Well sir, if that's what you think, you don't know the makers!
They did not relax. They took their good Marlboros and kept
improving them. They improved the filter, improved the blend,
improved the pack. They researched and developed tirelessly,
until today Marlboro is just about the most admirable cigarette
you can put a match to. There are, in fact, some people who
find Marlboros so admirable they can't bear to put a match to
them. They just sit with a single Marlboro in hand and admire
it for ten, twelve years on end. The makers of Marlboro are of
course deeply touched by this—except for E. Rennie Sigafoos,
the sales manager.
But I digress. The ACP, I say, is good but it can be better.
Why should the plan be confined to small colleges? Why should
it be confined to a limited region? Why not include all colleges
and universities, big and small, wherever they are?
Let's start such a federation. Let's call it the "Bigger Associated Colleges To Encourage Richer Intellectual Activity"—
BACTERIA,for short!

What a bright new world BACTERIA opens up. Take, for
example, a typical college student —Hunrath Sigafoos (son,
incidentally, of the Marlboro sales manager). Hunrath,a bright
lad, is currently majoring in burley at the University of Kentucky. Under the BACTERIA plan, Hunrath could stay at
Kentucky, where he has made many friends, but at the same
time broaden his vistas by taking a course in constitutional law
at Harvard, a course in physics at Caned], a course in frostbite
at Minnesota and a course in poi at Hawaii!
I admit there are still a few bugs in BACTERIA. How, for
instance, could Hunrath attend a 9 o'clock class at Harvard,
a 10 o'clock class at Hawaii, an 11 o'clock class at Minnesota,
and still keep his lunch date at Kentucky? It would be idle to
deny that this is a tricky problem, but I have no doubt American
ingenuity will carry the day. Always remember how they
laughed at Edison and Fulton—and particularly at Walter
Clavicle who invented the collarbone.

Technical representatives
of the MITRE Corporation
will be conducting interviews
on campus
MARCH 2, 1962
MITRE now has openings for talented men who want to
work in the challenging new field of system engineering... a
set of skills defined in only the most recent reference books.
With MITRE,system engineering embraces such electronic
command and control systems as the NORAD Intelligence
Function and the manned bomber defense, SAGE.
The work is vital. Time for decision in aerospace operations has been compressed intolerably. Today's military
leaders must have help in commanding forces of awesome
strength. They need great quantities of information electronically transmitted, processed and displayed. This is the
challenge of command and control...the work of the men at
MITRE.
Formed under the sponsorship of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, MITRE is a growing engineering
research corporation with 1,600 employees,over 600 of which
comprise the technical staff. It serves as technical advisor to
the U. S. Air Force and other government agencies and engages in system design, conceptual planning, evaluation of
electronic systems and research development.
Appointments will be made principally in the Suburban
Boston area. Openings are also available at facilities in
Washington, D. C. and Colorado Springs, Colo. Brochures
describing the activities of The MITRE Corporation are
available on request at the placement office.

THE BROTHERS FOUR

The University Prom, featuring Billy Butterfield and the Brothers Four, will be held
in the Fifth Regiment Armory on Saturday,
March 10 from 8 P.M. to 1 A.M. Dress will be
semi-formal.
Tickets will cost three dollars per couple
for undergraduates, five dollars for others and
may be obtained at Levering, the Dorm Cafeteria, the Student Valet Service, or from
members of the Cotillion Board, the H-Club,
The Booster Club, the I.F.C., the Student
Council and the D.S.R.C. Graduate students
and students of McCoy College may get tickets
at the Bookstore or in Levering. Tickets will
also be on sale at the Registrar's office at the
Med School.
The Cotillion Board has stressed that no
efforts have been spared to make this Prom
the best in the history of Hopkins. The favors
and decorations are designed to be truly
memorable and to harmonize with the particular tonal qualities of the Billy Butterfield

Orchestra. It is hoped that this harmony will
lend an aesthetic unity to the dance as a
whole and thus make it a more pleasant experience.
In order to insure the financial success of
the dance, members of the graduate departments, Medical School and employees are
being actively solicited. It is stressed that this
is a function for the whole Hopkins Community, not only for the undergraduates. It is
hoped that many grad students, medical students and employees will attend.
..Table reservations are available from Terry
Sinclair, 285 - 1868, until one week before the
dance. No reservations will be accepted after
March 3.
John Wetzig, Chairman of the dance committee issued the following statement, "We
really hope all you fellows will have a real
good time at the Prom. We have put a lot of
work into it and we really think that this will
help to liven up the old Homewood."

At Shriver

By Matt Crenson
Mr. Harry Golden, essayist, journalist,
and shirtsleeve philosopher from the South,
is scheduled to speak at Shriver Hall this
Sunday evening in a program sponsored by
the YMCA and Student Council. The talk,
by the editor of the Carolina Israelite, will
bring to a close Brotherhood Week activities at Hopkins.
Mr. Golden is the author of three books,
the first of which, Only in America, sold
over two million copies and was translated
into fifty-four languages. He is about to
publish a fourth—a collection of essays
called You're Entitle.
Born in New York, Golden was educated
at the East Side Evening High School and
CCNY, taught elementary school for two
years, and worked as a reporter for two
New York newspapers. In 1941 he moved
to Charlotte, North Carolina, where he took
over the Israelite, which then
commanded a subscription list of
400. Circulation has subsequently
risen to more than 300,000.

Program in general, Ed Morse
expressed regret that the Administration was unwilling to
provide more funds to bring superior speakers to campus; however, he emphasized that the
scheduled speeches of Norman
Thomas and Dr. Eisenhower
should be of interest to the entire Hopkins community and he
strongly recommended that Hopkins men attend these lectures.
Also on the Student Council
program is William F. Buckley,
Jr., who will speak April 27.

HARRY GOLDEN

A referendum will be submitted to the student body on
the following Tuesday, March 6,
to at which time a vote will
be taken to decide whether or
not to institute the Gentleman's
Code Commission. The proposal
must receive a simple majority
of those voting in order to pass.
Earlier Elections
At the same time the Council
will ask for student approval of
an amendment to its Constitution which would move the date
of Student Council elections
from late in April to late in
March. Under the new plan
elections would be held just before Spring Vacation.

MILTON EISENHOWER

In advocating this change Bob
Abernethy, President of the
Student Council, stated that he
felt that the new system would

be a great improvement because
it would allow the new council
an extra month to get its
projects under way before the
closing of school. This, Abernethy felt, would make for con-.
siderably less confusion in the
fall.
For Losers
As a part of the new election
procedure it is proposed that the
elections for President of the
Council be held one week before
the election of Council members.
This would give defeated candidates for President a chance
to run for the Council and thus
not exclude potentially valuable
men from student government.

support for this proposal, at least
one Council member remarked
that if this plan were put into
effect the council would soon
become "a group of losers."

The Defeated One?
The Student Council this week passed an interesting constitutional amendment requiring elections for
the president of the Council to be held one week prior
to the election for Student Council representatives.
The avowed purpose of this amendment is to make
sure that no "campus leaders" are prevented from serving on the Council. In other words, if a presidential
candidate loses, he may still run for representative. A
sponsor of this amendment was Bill Brandon. Our only
question is whether defeatism has set in at such an early
date.

By nature student government either is or is not;
there can be no half-way state. The ideal of all student government is the situation where the students
assume complete responsibility for their conduct, their
organizations, and their discipline. Opposed to this is
the situation where the administration assumes all these
functions.
If we admit that the college student is an adult,
then he should be allowed to govern himself completely
and without interference. If this is denied, there is no
reason to have any student government at all.
The half and half combination favored on this
rampus can not succeed. Like all governments subject
to two masters our student government is forced to
please everybody simultaneously. Patently, this situation
can not be permanently maintained with corresponding
loss of confidence in the student government by both
administration and student bodies.
For student government to be meaningful it must
Lave complete responsibility for all student affairs including discipline, legislation, and finance. The function of the dean should be merely advisory, not directive.
In this situation student government passes from
the trivial to the important. The actual policies of the
government may be laissez-faire or controlled depending on the wishes of the student body. But the decisions
would be made solely by the student body according
to their desires and interests without reference to any
other master.

At long last the American student seems anxious to
shake off his tratltional political apathy. Last weekend
thousands of American students from all over the nation converged on Washington, D.C. in a truly impressive
ad moving demonstration of student unity and determination. They made the pilgrimage in order to impress the United States government and people with
the urgency of effecting a lasting peace in the world
and with the uselessness of bomb shelters.
The appeal was eloquent. It could not be passed off
I
as the idea of crack-pot leftists or that of immature
youngsters. President John Kennedy recognized the
legitimacy of student concern for international affairs—
going so far as to order that a large urn of coffee be
sent out to picketers pacing in front of the White House.
Inside the White House, three of his top aides met cordially with student representatives and discussed the
problem. The students got short shrift from Congressmen, but then again what more could be expected from
those gentlemen.
The reason for this rebirth of student political
411.
activity is still unclear. It remains microscopic compared
to students peace movements in Europe and Asia. But
in passing we note that it is occurring at the same time
as the conservative factions on campuses have become
somewhat more active. It is also accompanied by a corresponding decline in the power and prestige of campus
student government organization all over the country.

Fifty-sixth Street, is formally the
home of the Phi Gamma Delta
Club. And the Hopkins Club, together with the Stevens Institute
of Technology, the Syracuse and
the Metropolitan Clubs, do but
share the facilities of Phi Gamma
Delta.
That Old Hospitality
There is no doorman to await
one's arrival or to signify the
presence of the Club, so it is quite
usual to pass the entrance several
times before going in. Should one
enter in a black and blue packet
labeled "HOPKINS," he will be
shaken to the rude realization
that no one has or will approach
him with a friendly handshake,
to inquire if the old place is still
located on the Homewood campus.

There are nine floors to the
narrow building. On the second
may indeed be found a library
and a lounge, as stipulated by the
advertisement. The library is not
bright and doesn't have many
books; if it is richly paneled, one
could hardly note the fact since
the walls are quite liberally
adorned with framed documents
of the Phi Gamma Delta Club.
The lounge has most likely been
designed in imitation of a Charles
Dickens description of the solemn
old English drawing-room. As in
the library, a considerable dearth
of light makes itself felt. There
is, however, a piano in the corner.
The Setting
Some might substantiate the
Club's claim that it possesses
"outstanding" facilities. From the
windows facing the street one
gets an excellent panorama of
life in downtown New York.
There is a construction project
directly across the street, adding
greatly to the setting's local color
and general impact.
And, if one looks hard enough,
he might even find a plaque stating "Johns Hopkins Slept Here."
But that's highly doubtful.

UNITED WE STAND
The entire academic world is agog over the success of the
Associated Colleges Plan—ACP, for short. I mean, you go to
any campus in the country these days and you will see students
and faculty dancing on the green, blowing penny whistles,
grabbing each other by the elbows and yelling, "About that
ACP, Charley—like wow!"
And who can blame them? The ACP is a plan not only simply
brilliant, but also brilliantly simple. All it is, is a loose regional
federation of small colleges. Let's say, for example, that in a
given region we have a group of small colleges, each with its
own academic specialty. Small College No. 1, let's say,has a fine
language department; Small College No. 2, let's say, has a fine
science department; No.3 has a fine music department; etc., etc.
Well sir, under the ACP these various colleges federate. A
student in any one of the colleges can take courses in the specialty of any of the other colleges and—here's the beauty part!
—he will receive credit for the course at his home college. Thus
he enjoys all the advantages of a big university without losing
the comfy coziness of a small college!
Well sir, you can see what a good idea the ACP is. I respectfully submit, however, that just because a thing is good is no
reason not to try to make it better. Like,for instance, Marlboro
Cigarettes. Marlboros were good from the very beginning, and
people found out quickly and sales zoomed. But did the makers
of Marlboro say, "Okay, we've got it made. Let's relax"?
Well sir, if that's what you think, you don't know the makers!
They did not relax. They took their good Marlboros and kept
improving them. They improved the filter, improved the blend,
improved the pack. They researched and developed tirelessly,
until today Marlboro is just about the most admirable cigarette
you can put a match to. There are, in fact, some people who
find Marlboros so admirable they can't bear to put a match to
them. They just sit with a single Marlboro in hand and admire
it for ten, twelve years on end. The makers of Marlboro are of
course deeply touched by this—except for E. Rennie Sigafoos,
the sales manager.
But I digress. The ACP, I say, is good but it can be better.
Why should the plan be confined to small colleges? Why should
it be confined to a limited region? Why not include all colleges
and universities, big and small, wherever they are?
Let's start such a federation. Let's call it the "Bigger Associated Colleges To Encourage Richer Intellectual Activity"—
BACTERIA,for short!

What a bright new world BACTERIA opens up. Take, for
example, a typical college student —Hunrath Sigafoos (son,
incidentally, of the Marlboro sales manager). Hunrath,a bright
lad, is currently majoring in burley at the University of Kentucky. Under the BACTERIA plan, Hunrath could stay at
Kentucky, where he has made many friends, but at the same
time broaden his vistas by taking a course in constitutional law
at Harvard, a course in physics at Caned], a course in frostbite
at Minnesota and a course in poi at Hawaii!
I admit there are still a few bugs in BACTERIA. How, for
instance, could Hunrath attend a 9 o'clock class at Harvard,
a 10 o'clock class at Hawaii, an 11 o'clock class at Minnesota,
and still keep his lunch date at Kentucky? It would be idle to
deny that this is a tricky problem, but I have no doubt American
ingenuity will carry the day. Always remember how they
laughed at Edison and Fulton—and particularly at Walter
Clavicle who invented the collarbone.

Meno, for I understand that at
least six Chamber scholars must
be included on the Code Commission, and at least three must
sit on the Trial Committee when
a Chamber scholar is being tried.
Your latter point I know nothing
about.
PROTUS: I am informed on
this matter, Anytus, and a difficult one it is. For in the first
place, the fact is that the Ministers of the Living Chambers
would retain their Judicial Council under the present Code Commission Constitution. But since
the Constitution also specifically
states that the Code Commission
would handle cases involving
rioting among the scholars, the
main functions of the Judicial
Council would be taken away,
leaving it with only the handling
of minor problems. Some of the
Ministers feel that the Judicial
Council should have full powers
in its own territory — but this
would include riot jurisdiction.
Others, however, would rather
turn all judicial functions of the
Ministers of the Living Chambers
over to the Code Commission.
However, this would bring an
end to the Judicial Council.
ANYTUS: Some have said that
while the newly formed Judicial
Council is constitutionally constructed in quite a fine fashion,
there can be little doubt that the
Code Commission is better constructed. And they affirm this
because it is constructed in a
way that is almost identical with
that of the Academic Honor
Council, which has stood the test
of time.
MENO: I see, Anytus, that you
are beginning to realize one of
the greatest negative points
about the Code Commission. That
point is its relation to the Ministers of the Living Chambers and
their Judicial Council. Indeed,
the original purpose in forming
the Code Commission was to unify all judicial functions at the
Academy into one unit, thereby
eliminating hazy boundaries of
jurisdiction and also regularizing
punishments given for like misdemeanors. But, Anytus and
Prolus, this purpose has not
been accomplished, and will not
be accomplished until the Judicial Council is done away with.
ANYTUS: Your argument is an
excellent one, Meno. Perhaps you
may convince me even more if
you will comment on item D
under section number one of the
Code Commission Constitution.
MENO: You refer to the omnibus clause which gives the Board
of Governors the right to declare
any action a violation of the
non-academic code of living
standards. This is a fine example
of the governors' grasping for
power.
PROTUS: I cannot deny the
existence of this clause, yet close
examination will reveal that it
is not so bad after all. In the first
place, the Board of Governors
already has this power, regardless of the existence of the Code
Commission. Secondly, history

Technical representatives
of the MITRE Corporation
will be conducting interviews
on campus
MARCH 2, 1962
MITRE now has openings for talented men who want to
work in the challenging new field of system engineering... a
set of skills defined in only the most recent reference books.
With MITRE,system engineering embraces such electronic
command and control systems as the NORAD Intelligence
Function and the manned bomber defense, SAGE.
The work is vital. Time for decision in aerospace operations has been compressed intolerably. Today's military
leaders must have help in commanding forces of awesome
strength. They need great quantities of information electronically transmitted, processed and displayed. This is the
challenge of command and control...the work of the men at
MITRE.
Formed under the sponsorship of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, MITRE is a growing engineering
research corporation with 1,600 employees,over 600 of which
comprise the technical staff. It serves as technical advisor to
the U. S. Air Force and other government agencies and engages in system design, conceptual planning, evaluation of
electronic systems and research development.
Appointments will be made principally in the Suburban
Boston area. Openings are also available at facilities in
Washington, D. C. and Colorado Springs, Colo. Brochures
describing the activities of The MITRE Corporation are
available on request at the placement office.
